Detailed Description

The OWL Data object.

This class contains DB datasets

Author:
Oscar van Eijk, Oveas Functionality Provider
Version:
Aug 4, 2008 -- O van Eijk -- initial version

Constructor & Destructor Documentation

DataHandler::__construct ( $  tablename = ''  ) 

Class constructor. We don't use a standard constructor (__construct()) here, since singleton classes (using private constructors) might derive from this class. In stead we use the PHP4 compatible constructor.

Parameters:
[in] $tablename Default table name for this dataset

References OWL::factory(), _OWL::init(), and _OWL::set_status().

Member Function Documentation

_OWL::check ( &$  object,
$  level = OWL_WARNING 
) [protected, inherited]

This is a helper function for lazy developers. Some checks have to be made quite often, this is a kinda macro to handle that. It compares the own severity level with that of a given object. If the highest level is above a given max, a traceback and reset are performed.

Parameters:
[in] $object Pointer to an object to check against
[in] $level The maximum severity level
Returns:
True if the severity level was correct ( below the max), otherwise false

References _OWL::reset(), _OWL::set_high_severity(), and _OWL::traceback().

Referenced by SessionHandler::write().

&$  expanded 
) [private]

Try to exand a field to a fully qualified 'table#field' name

Parameters:

[out] $expanded An array with all matching fully qualified fieldnames.
Returns:
The number of matches

Referenced by get().

DataHandler::get ( $  variable  ) 

Retrieve a value from the data array. The variable name can be a fully qualified table/fieldname (format "table#field"), or only a field name, in which case it has to be unique. If the fieldname cannot be found directly, the array is scanned to find a matching field. If more matches are found, the object status is set to DATA_AMBFIELD.

Parameters:
[in] $variable The name of the variable that should be retrieved
Returns:
The value, or NULL when the value was not found or abigious.

References find_field(), and _OWL::set_status().

_OWL::init (  )  [protected, inherited]

This function should be called by all constuctors. It initializes the general characteristics. Status is 'warning' by default, it's up to the contructor to set a proper status; if it's still 'warning', this *might* indicate something went wrong.

References OWL::factory(), and _OWL::set_status().

DataHandler::prepare ( $  type = DATA_READ  ) 

Prepare a database query

Parameters:
[in] $type Specify which type of query should be prepared:

  • DATA_READ (default); Read data from the database
  • DATA_WRITE; Write new data to the database
  • DATA_UPDATE; Update data in the database
Returns:
Severity level

References $_t, $_table, _OWL::set_high_severity(), and _OWL::set_status().

DataHandler::set ( $  variable,
$  value 
)

Define or override a variable in the data array

Parameters:
[in] $variable The name of the variable that should be set
[in] $value Value to set the variable to. If this is an array, the second field in the array has to be the tablename where the fieldname is found. The value itself van NEVER be an array!

_OWL::set_high_severity ( &$  object = null  )  [protected, inherited]

Compare the severity level of the current object with a given one and set my statuspointer to the object with the highest level.

DataHandler::set_join ( $  lvalue,
$  rvalue,
$  linktype = '=' 
)

Define a link between 2 fields that will be recognized when the database query is built.

Parameters:
[in] $lvalue Left value as array(table, field)
[in] $rvalue Right value as array(table, field)
[in] $linktype How are the fields linked. Can be any binary operator as recognized by SQL.
Returns:
Severity level

References _OWL::set_status().

DataHandler::set_key ( $  variable  ) 

Lock variables for update by adding them to an array. Fields in this array will not be overwritten on updates, but used in WHERE clauses.

Parameters:
[in] $variable Variable name to lock, optionally as an array (table, field)
Returns:
Severity level

References _OWL::get_severity(), and _OWL::set_status().

DataHandler::set_prefix ( $  prefix  ) 

Overwrite the table prefix for this dataset. Since the prefix is stored in the database handler object, a clone is made here.

Parameters:
[in] $prefix Table prefix

References OWL::factory().

_OWL::traceback ( &$  text = false,
$  depth = 0 
) [inherited]

If somehwere in the nested calls an error occured, we can traceback the original failing object with this function and signal the message.

Parameters:
[out] $text Optional variable in which the message text can be stored. If not given, the text will be written to standard output
[in] $depth This paramater should be initially empty. It calculates the depth in recursive calls.
Returns:
Severity code of the failing object

References _OWL::signal().

Referenced by _OWL::check(), UserHandler::login(), and SessionHandler::read().

Member Data Documentation

DataHandler::$owl_data [private]

Indexed array holding all data values.

DataHandler::$owl_database [private]

An optional link to a database object. This has to be specified if the data needs to be written to or read from a dabatase.

DataHandler::$owl_joins [private]

2D Array holding all relationships between the data.

DataHandler::$owl_keys [private]

Array with variable names that are used in WHERE clauses on updates

DataHandler::$owl_prepared [private]

Boolean that indicates of a query has been prepared

DataHandler::$owl_tablename [private]

All variable names are expected to be fields in a database as well. If a table name is not given, the default table name will be used. This is useful for datasets that come from only one database table. For datasets that are not read from or written to a database, the tablename can be null.

_OWL::$severity [protected, inherited]

Severity level of the current object status
